answers: The Trasimeno climate is quite warm, and has moderate winters. Summers can be very warm and humid, but in general the lake moderates the climate both in cold and warm conditions due to a moderate themic inertia of shallow water. From May to September, the temperature is high enough to allow swimming. A cold winter froze the whole of the lake's surface in 1929, and cars could be driven over the ice. Cold winters in 1957, 1985 and 2002 brought about heavy damage to the olive trees nearby.

question: person: I am interested in car. I would like to visit USA. I am interested in the history. I like to research about historic buildings. I like to research about historic figures. context: Q: Where is this place? R: What is the place known for? Q: What is the history of this place?
answers: As you are interested in history, The right-of-way now used by the Willamette Shore Trolley was established in the mid-1880s by the Portland and Willamette Valley Railway, which began passenger service with steam trains on July 4, 1887. It provided Oswego (as Lake Oswego was known then) with a direct link to Portland. Prior to this, access to Oswego was limited to primitive roads and river boats.

question: person: I am interested in car. I would like to visit USA. I am interested in the history. I like to research about historic buildings. answers: Several local governments in the area established a not-for-profit corporation to acquire the line and preserve the right-of-way for future mass transit after the Interstate Commerce Commission granted Southern Pacific permission to abandon the line. This consortium of governmental entities was initially composed of Metro, TriMet, the cities of Portland and Lake Oswego, and the counties of Multnomah and Clackamas, and it was joined by the Oregon Department of Transportation (ODOT).

question: person: I am interested in car. I would like to visit USA. I am interested in the history. I like to research about historic buildings. answers: In 1987, a temporary, trial heritage trolley service was operated on the line to gauge public interest in such an operation. This servicce was inaugurated in September 1987 by the Oregon Electric Railway Historical Society (OERHS), using a double-deck trolley originally from Blackpool, England.

question: person: I would like to visit England. I am interested in Benedictine monastery. I am interested in history. I am interested in famous people. I am interested in shopping. context: Q: Where is this place? R: What is the place known for? Q: What is the history of this place?
answers: As you are interested in history, In 597, Augustine came to England, having been sent by the missionary-minded Pope Gregory I to convert the Anglo-Saxons. The King of Kent at this time was Æthelberht or Ethelbert. Although he worshipped in a pagan temple just outside the walls of Canterbury to the east of the city, Ethelbert was married to Bertha who is a Christian. According to tradition, the king ordered that the church to be erected be of "becoming splendour, dedicated to the blessed apostles Peter and Paul, and endowed it with a variety of gifts." as well as he gave his temple and its precincts to St Augustine for a church and monastery. One purpose of the foundation was to build a residence for Augustine and his brother monks. Another purpose is a burial place for abbots, archbishops, and kings of Kent.

question: person: I would like to visit England. I am interested in Benedictine monastery. I am interested in history. I am interested in famous people. I am interested in shopping. context: R: What is the place known for? Q: What is the history of this place? R: What is Dunstan's reform?
answers: Dunstan, Archbishop of Canterbury from 959 to 988, influenced a reconstruction of the abbey to conform to Benedictine rule. Buildings were expanded and the church rebuilt. Dunstan also added Saint Augustine in 978 and revised the dedication of the abbey, from the original Saints Peter and Paul. Since then, the abbey has been known as St Augustine's.

question: person: I would like to visit England. I am interested in Benedictine monastery. I am interested in history. I am interested in famous people. I am interested in shopping. context: Q: What is the history of this place? R: What is Dunstan's reform? Q: What is Invading Danes?
answers: The invading Danes not only spared St Augustine's, but King Cnut made over all the possessions of Minster-in-Thanet to St Augustine's in 1027. The preserved body of Saint Mildred is one of these possessions. Many pilgrims came to St Augustine's with belief in the miraculous power.

question: person: I would like to visit England. I am interested in Benedictine monastery. I am interested in history. I am interested in famous people. I am interested in shopping. context: R: What is Dunstan's reform? Q: What is Invading Danes? R: What is Norman conquest?
answers: After the Norman Conquest of England in 1066, William the Conqueror confiscated landed estates, but he respected Church property. The Anglo-Saxon buildings were completely reconstructed in the form of a typical Norman Benedictine monastery at St Augustine's Abbey. All the original buildings had disappeared under a Romanesque edifice by 1100. There was further reconstruction as a result of the great fire in 1168. The fire's destruction results in the paucity of historical records for the preceding period.

answers: The gardens at Chiswick House are thought to be one of the earliest examples of the English landscape garden. The gardens were an attempt to symbolically recreate a garden of ancient Rome and have been in a constant state of transition from the 1720s. There have been a diverse range of elements introduced such as a Ha-ha, classical fabriques, statues, groves, faux Egyptian objects, winding walks and water features and casades.

The new signal box controlled 295 sets of points and 446 signals and detected occupancy on 300 sections of track and seven automatic block sections. answers: As you are interested in Hardenbergh structure, I will tell you that the initial structure by Hardenbergh was one of the architect's last designs. The original plans called for a 12-story building with a facade made of limestone. In the original plans, the lowest three levels were to contain storefronts, with double-height segmental arches along the facade of the ground and second floors. On the middle seven levels, the windows were to be recessed into architectural bays, with each bay containing three windows on each floor. The top two levels were to contain windows that were recessed into the facade, separated by colonettes in the Ionic order, as well as decorated spandrels within the windows.

Evidence for human activity in the Neolithic and early Bronze Age has been found, but not settlement or occupation. The finds consisted of tools likely to have been used for exploiting woodland. answers: As you are interested in history, The Jerusalem Biblical Zoo opened in September 1940 as a small "animal corner" on Rabbi Kook Street in central Jerusalem. The zoo was founded by Aharon Shulov, a professor of zoology at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Mount Scopus. Among Shulov's goals were to provide a research facility for his students; to gather animals, reptiles and birds mentioned in the Bible; and, as he wrote in 1951, to break down the "invisible wall" between the intellectuals on Mount Scopus and the general public.

question: person: I am interested in theater. I would like to visit USA. I like to research about historic buildings. I am interested in the history. I am interested in art. context: Q: Where is this place? R: What is the place known for? Q: What is the history of this place?
answers: As you are interested in history, The Bijou stands on Lot 38 of the original survey of Knoxville drawn by Charles McClung in 1791. Thomas Humes, who operated a nearby store on Gay Street, purchased parts of the lot in 1801 and 1805. In 1816, Humes began building the three-story structure on the lot that he planned to operate as a tavern and hotel, but died before the building was completed. Humes's widow, Margaret Russell Cowan, continued construction, however, and the "Knoxville Hotel" opened sometime around July 1817.

question: person: I am interested in theater. I would like to visit USA. I like to research about historic buildings. I am interested in the history. I am interested in art. context: R: What is the place known for? Q: What is the history of this place? R: What is the structure of the place?
answers: The Bijou Theatre building consists of two parts. One is the original hotel section and the other one is the rear theater section. The main entrance opens into a foyer, from which the rear theater section and the building's front corner wings are accessed. From the foyer, the rear entrance opens into a bar, with passageways to the left and right leading to the theater's orchestra floor, and stairways to the left and right accessing the theater's balconies and the original building's second floo.

question: person: I am interested in theater. I would like to visit USA. I like to research about historic buildings. I am interested in the history. I am interested in art. context: Q: What is the history of this place? R: What is the structure of the place? Q: What is Lamar House and the Civil War?
answers: Since you are a history-lover, you will like this story. In the months leading up to the Civil War, the Lamar House was favored by the city's secessionist leaders. District Attorney J. C. Ramsey, who ruthlessly prosecuted the city's Unionists during the war, listed the hotel as his business address. In October 1860, ex-Congressman John H. Crozier delivered a pro-secession speech in front of the hotel in which he called the city's pro-Union newspaperman, Parson Brownlow, a "coward." During the Confederate Army's occupation of Knoxville (1861–1863), Confederate officers boarded at the Lamar House.

question: person: I'm going on an exploratory trip to Oregon. I love to climb mountains. I like to look at the landscape in lookouts. I have been pursuing leisure activities. I care about the local fauna and flora. context: Q: Wow, this is amazing! What is this?
answers: Ever since you told me you're going on an exploratory trip to Oregon, I've been looking for places that might interest you, so I found Roxy Ann Peak, also known as Roxy Ann Butte, a 3,576-foot-high mountain in the Western Cascade Range in east end of Medford, Oregon.

question: person: I'm going on an exploratory trip to Oregon. I love to climb mountains. I like to look at the landscape in lookouts. I have been pursuing leisure activities. I care about the local fauna and flora. context: R: Wow, this is amazing! What is this? Q: Wow! It seems like an interesting place! Tell me more about this place.
answers: As you love to climb mountains, you will like to know about the formation of this important mountain; Roxy Ann Peak is made up of several geological layers, and most of its peak is of volcanic origin originating from the Oligocene era; the topographic prominence of the peak is relatively small, at 753 feet, rising to 2,200 feet above Medford; externally on its lower slopes they are covered by savanna vegetation with oaks and open pastures and on the upper slopes and ridge, it is formed by mixed coniferous forests, stopping before the summit; its importance for the city of Medford is inducible, as it has an unparalleled recreational resource.

question: person: I'm going on an exploratory trip to Oregon. I love to climb mountains. I like to look at the landscape in lookouts. I have been pursuing leisure activities. I care about the local fauna and flora. context: Q: Wow, this is amazing! What is this? R: Wow! It seems like an interesting place! Tell me more about this place. Q: What leisure activities are available at Roxy Ann Peak?
answers: When I told you about this mountain, it was not by chance, I know that here you will find the leisure you are always looking for; starting with your own view of the lookout, which you love, hiking, picnicking, mountain biking and horseback riding; on the mountain you can choose from the 6 km of designated trails in Prescott Park, which vary in difficulty, from moderate to steep. Some private companies want to help improve mountain and conservation activities by creating private recreational activities on site, for example, we have the International Mountain cycling Association, which launched a conceptual plan detailing future improvements to the park's trail system and the Prescott Park itself which launched in 2012 a Challenge Course, operated by Synergo.

question: person: I'm going on an exploratory trip to Oregon. I love to climb mountains. I like to look at the landscape in lookouts. I have been pursuing leisure activities. R: I got curious. Tell me about this challenge course operated by Synergo?
answers: This is a very interesting course, the company Synergo, based in Tigard, created this course based on 15 elements - eight low and seven high - vary from 2 to 40 feet (0.61 to 12 m) above the ground, each one is formed by various combinations of ropes, wires, platforms, ladders and swings, I believe that it can be classified as a more radical activity and that requires a certain level of fitness.

question: person: I'm going on an exploratory trip to Oregon. I love to climb mountains. I like to look at the landscape in lookouts. I have been pursuing leisure activities. Q: What can you tell me about the local fauna and flora?
answers: As you have been concerned with the fauna and flora, I believe that at the Roxy Ann peak you will find a high biodiversity present in the lower slopes of the peak with oak savanna vegetation and open pastures. These conditions include sclerophilous shrubs, Oregon white oak, grasses such as blue wildrye and prairie Junegrass; the mountain peak is also home to many species of birds, while the mammals that inhabit the mountain include black-tailed deer, cougars, lynx, skunks, raccoons.

question: person: I'm going on an exploratory trip to Oregon. I love to climb mountains. I like to look at the landscape in lookouts. I have been pursuing leisure activities. R: How can I get to the park to access the Roxy Ann Peak?
answers: You can access the peak and park via Roxy Ann Road, on the south side of the mountain; there are two gates on the road; the first is close to the base of the peak and is open and closed at a set time, and the second is about a mile beyond, on the edge of the park, and is closed to all unauthorized motor vehicles. if you drive another mile past the second gate, the road splits in a 2.7 mile loop around the summit, this is where Tower Road starts on the north side of the circuit and climbs to the top of the peak.

answers: In 2001, ownership of the Seattle SuperSonics, who had called KeyArena home since 1967, transferred from Barry Ackerley to Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz, but after failing to arrive at an agreement with the city of Seattle over a publicly funded $220 million expansion of KeyArena, the Basketball Club of Seattle, led by Schultz, put the SuperSonics and its sister team, the WNBA's Seattle Storm up for sale. After failing to find a local ownership group to sell the team to, Schultz talked to ownership groups from Kansas City, St. Louis, Las Vegas, San Jose and Anaheim before agreeing to sell the team on July 18, 2006 to an ownership group from Oklahoma City.

question: person: I like hiking. I am curious about wild turkey. I like fishing. I want to visit Maryland. I like white water rafting. context: R: Wow, this is amazing! What is this? Q: Any interesting fact about the Savage River State Forest?

question: person: I am interested in race. I would like to visit Australia. I am interested in the history. I am interested in the cars. I am interested in the racers. context: Q: Where is this place?
answers: This is The Bathurst 12 Hour located in Australia, which you want to visit.

question: person: I am interested in race. I would like to visit Australia. I am interested in the history. I am interested in the cars. I am interested in the racers. context: R: Where is this place? Q: What is the place known for?
answers: The Bathurst 12 Hour, currently known as the Liqui Moly Bathurst 12 Hour for sponsorship reasons, is an endurance race for GT and production cars held at the Mount Panorama Circuit, in Bathurst, Australia. since you are interested in race, you should visit this place.

question: person: I am interested in race. I would like to visit Australia. I am interested in the history. I am interested in the cars. I am interested in the racers. context: Q: Where is this place? R: What is the place known for? Q: What is the history of this place?
answers: As you are interested in history, in 1990, Vincent Tesoriero, a race promoter and former Bathurst 1000 competitor, looked at the decline of Group A touring cars in Australia and saw an opportunity to run a 12-hour endurance race for Series Production cars at Mount Panorama. Tesoriero secured long time Bathurst 1000 sponsor James Hardie as a sponsor for the event in late 1990, leaving limited time to launch and organise the event for the Easter weekend in 1991. The race regulations were based on the Group 3E Series Production Car rules then in use in the Australian Production Car Championship for naturally aspirated four- and six-cylinder passenger sedans, but also allowed turbocharged and V8-engined cars which had been outlawed from the Production Car Championship in 1990. Despite the short deadline, twenty-four cars were entered for the first race, spread over six different classes based on engine capacity and sporting specification. Exotic mid-engined sports cars and GT cars were not eligible to enter.

question: person: I am interested in volcanic plateaus. I would like to visit USA. I am interested in geology. I am interested in geography. I am interested in the nature. context: R: What is the place known for? Q: What is the history of this place? R: What is the geology of this place?
answers: For about 2.1 million years, the river deposited what is now known as the Payne Cliffs Formation by laying down a thin conglomerate, followed by arkosic sandstone and siltstone. Between 10 and 20 million years ago, the uplift that created the nearby Klamath Mountains caused an incision that formed the Rogue River valley. Vertical erosion, or downcutting of the Rogue River continues to keep pace with the recent uplift, with about 690 feet of erosion occurring in the past seven million years.

answers: As you are interested in history, the name Stockholm originally referred to Gamla Stan only, but as the city expanded, the name now also refers several suburban areas and the metro region. The name Stockholm means "log island" in Swedish. The previous capital of Sweden was in Sigtuna. A thousand years ago Sigtuna had problems with armed gangs attacking the city. The situation became untenable and there was a need to find a new location for the capital city of Sweden. According to legend the leaders in Sigtuna then took a log of wood, cut out all the wood inside, filled it with gold, and let it float on the water. The log was floating on the water for several days and eventually hit land on the island where Gamla Stan today is located.

answers: To describe the town, we should date back to the 13th century. It consisted of medieval alleyways, cobbled streets, and archaic architecture. North German architecture has had a strong influence in the Old Town's construction. Stortorget is the name of the scenic large square in the centre of Gamla Stan, which is surrounded by old merchants' houses including the Stockholm Stock Exchange Building. The square was the site of the Stockholm Bloodbath, where Swedish noblemen were massacred by the Danish King Christian II in 1520. The following revolt and civil war led to the dissolution of the Kalmar Union and the subsequent election of King Gustav I.

question: person: I would like to visit USA. I am interested in art collections. I am interested in contemporary art. I am interested in American art. answers: Yes. As you are interested in African art, the BMA was one of the first museums in the United States to obtain a collection of African art. In 1954, a large part of the collection was donated by Janet and Alan Wurtzburger. It has more than 2,000 objects whose sources range from ancient Egypt to contemporary Zimbabwe, and includes works from many other cultures, including Bamana, Yoruba, Kuba, Ndebele. There are many different forms of art, including headdresses, masks, figures, royal staffs, textiles, jewelry, ceremonial weapons, and pottery. answers: As you are interested in geography, Morrow Mountain is one of the highest peaks in the Uwharrie Mountains of central North Carolina. When first formed, these mountains rose to nearly 20,000 feet (6,100 m) above sea level, but erosion has gradually worn them down to little more than high hills that average less than 1,000 feet in elevation. These pinnacles are the remains of one of the oldest mountain ranges in the eastern United States. The park contains several peaks, of which Morrow Mountain is a high point at 936 feet (285 m).

At the Congress of Vienna, Austria insisted on the re-annexation of Salzburg, which had been made over to Bavaria by Napoleon after the Treaty of Schönbrunn in 1809. In the Treaty of Munich in 1816, Austria and Bavaria came to terms, with the Austrians promising to support Bavaria in its ambition to secure the County of Sponheim from Prussia and Baden's portion of the Palatinate on the right bank of the Rhine River following the death of the childless Grand Duke Charles of Baden.

For those who like exhibitions about animals, this museum will bring a lot of fun, as its collections include more than two million specimens that were collected between the 1910s and the present.

question: person: I am planning to take a trip to Canada. I love museums. I like to see exhibitions about animals. I love whales. What types of animals can be seen at the exhibitions?
answers: As I said, there is a lot to see at the Beaty Museum, so I will mention some of the most prominent collections; among them is the Cowan tetrapod collection, also the marine invertebrate collection, the fossil collection, the herbarium, Spencer's entomological collection, and the fish collection. But the museum's most prominent exhibit is undoubtedly the one that will please you most; it is an 82-foot skeleton of a female blue whale that is suspended on the ramp that leads to the main collections, I believe that this visit alone will be worth a lot because I know you love whales!

answers: The beautiful work of recostitution of this piece can be seen in the glass atrium of the museum, it is the largest skeleton of blue whale in Canada, and it is interesting to know that it is also the "largest skeleton exhibition in the world suspended without external structure for support" , which is very important, as there are only 21 blue whale skeletons on public display worldwide! Since you like animal fossils, maybe you are interested in seeing how the whale was recovered, transported and exhibited, you can see it all in a Discovery Channel documentary called Raising Big Blue; you can check out this documentary at the museum theater.
